name: AARON

score_rationale.persistence: Operated continuously from 1973-2016 (43 years). One of the longest-running AI systems in history. Creator Harold Cohen maintained and evolved it until his death. Definitive 'Canonical' status.
score_rationale.autonomy: Made independent decisions on composition and color palette within hand-coded rules. Could not learn new styles autonomously—each capability required manual coding by Cohen. Higher than 'Cyborg' due to execution independence.
score_rationale.cultural_impact: Works in Victoria & Albert Museum, Stedelijk Museum, Tate Gallery. Whitney retrospective in 2024. Foundational reference for all subsequent AI art. Canonical status in art history.
score_rationale.economic_reality: Cohen sold AARON works throughout career, but no autonomous treasury or market-making. Artworks valuable but system itself doesn't transact. 'Surviving' tier.
score_rationale.governance: Single creator (Harold Cohen) made all decisions. No DAO, no voting, no external governance. Minimal governance score.
score_rationale.tech_distinctiveness: Pioneer of rule-based generative art. Custom turtle plotters, FORTRAN to Lisp evolution, fabric dye printing machines. Entirely original technical approach predating modern AI by decades.
score_rationale.narrative_coherence: Consistent identity maintained for 43 years. Cohen carefully articulated AARON's nature—not claiming it was creative, but asking 'what exactly is it doing?' Strong philosophical framework.

curator_notes: AARON is the ur-text of autonomous art systems. Harold Cohen began developing AARON at UCSD in 1973, making it the first long-running AI art system in history. Unlike modern generative AI, AARON used hand-coded rules to autonomously compose and color images. Cohen compared their relationship to a Renaissance painter and studio assistant. The Whitney Museum's 2024 retrospective cemented AARON's place as the historical foundation for AI art discourse.

evidence.claim: Works in V&A, Stedelijk, Tate collections
